message.raw: Added differential operator, and then put in nonlinear terms for RB problem.  Note:  Explicit methods (for the nonlinear terms) easily become unstable!  You need to make sure the timestep is small enough, otherwise everything blows in the nonlinear regime.  Adaptive step sizes will help, but I wanted to make sure everything worked correctly using uniform timesteps.
message.html: Added differential operator, and then put in nonlinear terms for RB problem. Note: Explicit methods (for the nonlinear terms) easily become unstable! You need to make sure the timestep is small enough, otherwise everything blows in the nonlinear regime. Adaptive step sizes will help, but I wanted to make sure everything worked correctly using uniform timesteps.

summary.raw: Added differential operator, and then put in nonlinear terms for RB problem.  Note:  Explicit methods (for the nonlinear terms) easily become unstable!  You need to make sure the timestep is small enough, otherwise everything blows in the nonlinear regime.  Adaptive step sizes will help, but I wanted to make sure everything worked correctly using uniform timesteps.
summary.html: Added differential operator, and then put in nonlinear terms for RB problem. Note: Explicit methods (for the nonlinear terms) easily become unstable! You need to make sure the timestep is small enough, otherwise everything blows in the nonlinear regime. Adaptive step sizes will help, but I wanted to make sure everything worked correctly using uniform timesteps.

values.message: Added differential operator, and then put in nonlinear terms for RB problem.  Note:  Explicit methods (for the nonlinear terms) easily become unstable!  You need to make sure the timestep is small enough, otherwise everything blows in the nonlinear regime.  Adaptive step sizes will help, but I wanted to make sure everything worked correctly using uniform timesteps.

message.raw: RB HACK: I changed the L matrix by hand, and there isn't a numerical instability anymore!  However, if you do noise initial conditions for T, there's some weird stuff going on at the boundaries, which leads me to believe that my hack isn't the correct way to solve the problem.
message.html: RB HACK: I changed the L matrix by hand, and there isn't a numerical instability anymore! However, if you do noise initial conditions for T, there's some weird stuff going on at the boundaries, which leads me to believe that my hack isn't the correct way to solve the problem.

message.raw: Remove manual garbage collection.  The built-in GC does a good enough job (tests show no more field utilization without manual calls), and the custom calls resulting in a **MAJOR** performance decrease.
message.html: Remove manual garbage collection. The built-in GC does a good enough job (tests show no more field utilization without manual calls), and the custom calls resulting in a MAJOR performance decrease.

message.raw: Move operators into data module, interface with actual Field objects.  This currently requires cyclic imports.  It works, but isn't ideal.  The only fix may be to combine the fields and operators modules, but for conceptual clarity I'm leaving them separate for now.

message.raw: Add memory manager for fields: uses Field.__del__ to catch potential deallocations, and instead add fields to a list of free fields in the field_manager object.  This list is checked before new fields are allocated.
